question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

Which one of the following could be the schedule of the students' reports?
A) Mon. morning: Helen; Mon. afternoon: Robert Tues. morning: Olivia; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Lenore; Wed. afternoon: Kyle
B) Mon. morning: Irving; Mon. afternoon: Olivia Tues. morning: Helen; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Nina; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
C) Mon. morning: Lenore; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: George; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Robert; Wed. afternoon: Irving
D) Mon. morning: Nina; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: Robert; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Olivia; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
E) Mon. morning: Olivia; Mon. afternoon: Nina Tues. morning: Irving; Tues. afternoon: Helen Wed. morning: Kyle; Wed. afternoon: George

Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If Kyle and Lenore do not give reports, then the morning reports on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, respectively, could be given by
A) Helen, George, and Nina
B) Irving, Robert, and Helen
C) Nina, Helen, and Olivia
D) Olivia, Robert, and Irving
E) Robert, George, and Helen

If Kyle and Lennor do not do reports, the remaining are George H, Irving R, Nina O, Olivia L, Robert. Wait that's five students. Wait need six. Wait this is a problem. So those six are George (G), Helen(H), Irving(I), Nina(N), Olivia(O), Robert(R). So exactly six. So all of them must report. Wait because the problem is: "If Kyle AND Lenore DO NOT give REPORTS, then..." So in this scenario, the six reporters are G

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

Which one of the following is a pair of students who, if they give reports on the same day as each other, must give reports on Wednesday?
A) George and Lenore
B) Helen and Nina
C) Irving and Robert
D) Kyle and Nina
E) Olivia and Kyle
chain_of_thought:
<think>
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. So, we have eight students, and exactly six of them will give reports over three days (Mon, Tue, Wed), two each day. The conditions are a bit complex, but let's break them down one by one.

First, the main question is asking which pair of student, if chosen to report on the SAME day, must necessarily report on Wednesday. So even if they could be on other days, given they are paired on the day in question, that day has to be Wednesday.

Let me list out the conditions again to make sure I don't miss any:

1. **Tuesday is the ONLY day George can report.**
2. **Neither Olivia nor Robertson can give afternoon reports.** Wait, the name here is Robert, right? The students are listed as George, Helen,..., Robert. So maybe a typo, but assuming Robert is correct. So Olivia and Robert can't have afternoon reports.
3 **If Nina gives an oral report, THEN on the NEXT day Helen AND Irving must BOTH give reports. Unless Nina's REPORT is given ON WEDNESDAY.**

So, the key here is to figure out which pair, when scheduled on the Same day, forces that day to be Wed.

Let’s consider each option:

**A)George and Lenora** (Lenore, I think the last name is Lenore). Since George can only report on Tuesday (condition 1), if both George and someone else are on Tuesday. But the question is, if both are on the **same day**, must that day be Wednesday? But George can ONLY be on Thursday? Wait, no. "three consecutive days — Monday,Tuesday and Wednesday." So the three days are Monday to Wednesday. But George's only possible day is Tuesday (cond 1). So if George is scheduled on Tuesday with Lenore on Tuesday as well, then that day is Wednesday? Wait no. The days are fixed as Monday, Tues, Wed. So if both G and L are on, say, Tuesday (same day), then that day's reports are Tue. But since G must be there, the day must be Tuesday. So option A's pair would be on a day that must be Wednesday. No, wait. The question is: if the pair is scheduled to report ON the same DAY, then which day must that be Wednesday?

Wait, the answer choices are pairs of students. If those two students are scheduled to give reports ON the SAME DAY (i.e., they are both assigned to the same reporting day), which day would that have to be?

So for example, if George and another student are both scheduled on a particular day, then what day must it be? Since George's reports can only be on Tue, if the other student can be scheduled on any day except maybe some constraints, then if the two are on a same day, that day's assignment must include both. But if George can be there only on Tuesday except if the day is forced to be another. Wait no, George must be scheduled only on Tue. So the only possible days George can have are Tuesday. Therefore, any pair that includes George must have their common day as Tuesday. Because George can't be on any other day. Therefore option A: George and lenore must be both on Tuesday? But the answer is asking for which pair's common day must necessarily be Wednesday, but George can't. So perhaps A is incorrect.

Wait, but the question says "must give reports during Wednesday" if they are scheduled on Wednesday? No, the question states: "must be Wednesday" as the day they give their reports. Wait: "which one of... is a PAIR of students, if THEY give reports [on] the same [day], must give [reports] on Wednesday?" So if those two are assigned to a day, and that day must have been Wednesday. Because if they were on Monday or Tuesday, but given their constraints, that would be impossible. So we need to find a pair where their scheduled day can only possibly be Wednesday because of their constraints.

So let's re-examine each option.

**A: George & Lenore**

George can only give on Tuesday per condition 4. So any pair involving George must include Tuesday. Lenore has no restrictions except she's part of the six students. So unless there's a constraint that Lenore can't be scheduled with George on Tuesday because of something else, but I don't think so. So their common possible day would be Tuesday, not Wednesday. Therefore A is out.

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If George, Nina, and Robert give reports and they do so on different days from one another, which one of the following could be true?
A) Helen gives a report on Wednesday.
B) Nina gives a report on Monday.
C) Nina gives a report on Tuesday.
D) Olivia gives a report on Monday.
E) Robert gives a report on Wednesday.

Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If Kyle gives the afternoon report on Tuesday, and Helen gives the afternoon report on Wednesday, which one of the following could be the list of the students who give the morning reports on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, respectively?
A) Irving, Lenore, and Nina
B) Lenore, George, and Irving
C) Nina, Irving, and Lenore
D) Robert, George, and Irving
E) Robert, Irving, and Lenore

Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If Helen, Kyle, and Lenore, not necessarily in that order, give the three morning reports, which one of the following must be true?
A) Helen gives a report on Monday.
B) Irving gives a report on Monday.
C) Irving gives a report on Wednesday.
D) Kyle gives a report on Tuesday.
E) Kyle gives a report on Wednesday.

The organizer of a reading club will select at least five and at most six works from a group of nine works. The group consists of three French novels, three Russian novels, two French plays, and one Russian play. The organizer's selection of works must conform to the following requirements: No more than four French works are selected. At least three but no more than four novels are selected. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected.

Which one of the following could be the organizer's selection of works?
A) one French novel, two Russian novels, one French play, one Russian play
B) two French novels, one Russian novel, two French plays, one Russian play
C) two French novels, two Russian novels, two French plays
D) three French novels, one Russian novel, two French plays
E) three French novels, two Russian novels, one Russian play

The organizer of a reading club will select at least five and at most six works from a group of nine works. The group consists of three French novels, three Russian novels, two French plays, and one Russian play. The organizer's selection of works must conform to the following requirements: No more than four French works are selected. At least three but no more than four novels are selected. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected.

Which one of the following could be true about the organizer's selection of works?
A) No Russian novels are selected.
B) Exactly one French novel is selected.
C) All three plays are selected.
D) All three Russian novels are selected.
E) All five French works are selected.

The organizer of a reading club will select at least five and at most six works from a group of nine works. The group consists of three French novels, three Russian novels, two French plays, and one Russian play. The organizer's selection of works must conform to the following requirements: No more than four French works are selected. At least three but no more than four novels are selected. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected.

If the works selected include three French novels, which one of the following could be a complete and accurate list of the remaining works selected?
A) one Russian novel
B) two French plays
C) one Russian novel, one Russian play
D) one Russian novel, two French plays
E) two Russian novels, one French play

The organizer of a reading club will select at least five and at most six works from a group of nine works. The group consists of three French novels, three Russian novels, two French plays, and one Russian play. The organizer's selection of works must conform to the following requirements: No more than four French works are selected. At least three but no more than four novels are selected. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected.

The organizer must at least select
A) one French novel and one French play
B) one French novel and one Russian play
C) one Russian novel and one French play
D) two French novels
E) two Russian novels
